blog.name: gendrie
blog.title: fierce and terrible and hers
blog.description:
annalesa / 27 / pisces /
they would not make her yield

tags: i couldve done all 10 steps but
this is more than enough lol
summary: i had issues with the heroine's journey by marueen murdock but there were so many passages that made me think of arya. the book...
body:
i had issues with the heroine’s journey by marueen murdock but there were so many passages that made me think of arya. the book outlines a woman’s journey to self discovery and identity which is what arya’s arc is truly about. she begins her story as a girl suffering from feelings of inadequacy but on this journey she will reclaim the true sense of self that society (and war) tried to deny her. there are 10 steps but i found the descent to the underworld and mending of the mother/daughter split most interesting

The descent is characterized as a journey to the underworld, the dark night of the soul, the belly of the whale, the meeting of the dark goddess, or simply as depression. It is usually precipitated by a life-changing loss. Experiencing the death of one’s child, parent, or spouse with whom one’s life and identity has been closely intertwined may mark the beginning of the journey to the underworld. Women often make their descent when a particular role, such as daughterhood, motherhood, lover, or spouse, comes to an end. 

this is exactly what arya goes through after the red wedding. she’s experienced great losses before but this crushes her. that last bit of hope to be reunited with her family (her pack) and return home is shattered. arya becomes extremely depressed. she feels the loss of her daughterhood deeply thinking: She was no one’s daughter now. She was no one. Not Arya, not Weasel, not Nan nor Arry nor Squab, not even Lumpyhead. She was only some girl who ran with a dog by day, and dreamed of wolves by night. this sets arya on a path to braavos where she enters the house of black and white

In the underworld there is no sense of time; time is endless and you cannot rush your stay. There is no morning, day, or night. It is densely dark and unforgiving. This all-pervasive blackness is moist, cold, and bone-chilling. There are no easy answers in the underworld; there is no quick way out. Silence pervades when the wailing ceases. One is naked and walks on the bones of the dead.

the book uses the underworld as a metaphorical place but this is literally the environment arya experiences in the house of black and white and even braavos in general. its dark and cold and foggy. arya loses all sense of time while she’s in the temple caring for the dead and learning the arts of the faceless men. its a place that one could easily become lost in and one that will not be easy to escape.

At each of the seven gates she relinquishes aspects of her identity. This “unveiling suggests the removal of old illusions and false identities that may have served in the upper world but count for nothing in the Netherworld.”

in order to stay in the underworld arya had to rid herself of all her possessions. she threw everything she had into the water. even her clothes. all the symbols of her false identities - of which there were many - were not welcome. only no one can serve there. arya walks into the underworld empty handed and naked but she hides the symbol of her true self in the stone. arya will reclaim it after being “reborn” in the dark abyss of the hob&w. 

She may feel an incredible sense of emptiness, of being left out, shunned, left behind, without value. She may feel homeless, orphaned, in a place of in-between.

to arya her trauma feels like “a hole where [her] heart should be” the relentless loss has made her feel empty and without identity. she believes there is no place for her because winterfell has been burned. arya essentially feels dead. which is why she finds herself where she does in the underworld among those who worship death 

When a woman returns from the underworld dragging her bag of bones behind her, she yearns to be comforted, held, and nurtured.

first of all i just love the imagery of a woman walking out of the underworld dragging a bag of bones. second this is really what arya’s been searching for since before the story even started. she wants to be loved and accepted. in particular by her mother.

There are two poles of expression of the archetype of Mother: the Great Mother who embodies limitless nurturance, sustenance, and protection and the Terrible Mother who represents stasis, suffocation, and death.

catelyn stark and lady stoneheart represent this dichotomy of mothers. for all her flaws cat was a mother who loved her children very much. when all her children are taken from her she becomes stoneheart - a dark merciless figure of death and destruction. not unlike demeter when persephone was taken away to the underworld.

This tale of a rejected daughter who heals the outcast within herself by healing the madwoman who is her mother…

this books tells a story of a girl who was not treated well by her mother. there were several children she loved better but when they are killed the mother goes mad. in the end its the rejected daughter who saves her. the daughter washes and dresses and brushes her mothers hair as if the mother/daughter roles were reversed. in doing that she heals both of them. this is exactly why im so obsessed with an arya and lady stoneheart meeting. i think its the only way these two characters could find peace. arya feels rejected, unwanted, and desperately craves catelyn’s love. if she gets that acceptance from her mother it would lead to a feeling of true self acceptance. which is exactly where arya’s journey should take her.

summary: Please can you do a Gendrya story where Gendry is the crown prince and not a bastard and he names Arya the queen of love and...
question: Please can you do a Gendrya story where Gendry is the crown prince and not a bastard and he names Arya the queen of love and beauty after winning the jousting tournament? 💕
answer:
Thank you so much for the prompt :) I don’t think I ever wrote Gendry as the crown prince, that changes a lot about him and who he is… I tried to find the balance in that

The stupid stag was not going to do it. He was not. He was not. Arya kept repeating to herself. It had been a stupid bet Hot Pie from the Inn had proposed Gendry, with a easiness you normally didn’t see between a baker and a crown prince. Arya had obviously opposed the bet, multiple times, and she told him she wouldn’t accept it, so no, she couldn’t believe he was coming her way.

“My son,” Robert yelled with a laugh, “have you chosen a Queen of Love and Beauty?”

“Yes, Your Grace,” he answered and walked up to her, “My lady,” he greeted her, “I offer this crown to Lady Arya Stark.”

“No,” she answered with a smile to his own, as Mother and Sansa tried to stop her. “No,” she repeated.

“We’re quite in a impasse now, my lady. What do you purpose?” Gendry asked smiling - he knew why she was saying no, to challenge him.

“A competition. You win, I accept the crown; I win, I get the crown and name who I want.”

“Yes, yes, bring on another competition,” the King yelled from the place where he was seeing everything. “Choose, girl. Choose. A fighting spirit like my Lyanna.” Silence followed after that, as it was expected when King Robert brought up Lyanna - he had never married, saying that there would be no one to compare. But without heirs, he had chosen a few of his bastards to legitimize - Gendry had been one of the oldest and one of the closest to him, right here in King’s Landing.

“Prince Gendry, if you need the pick,” Arya finally spoke when King Robert had looked up from his grief.

“I’ll take your choice.”

“Archery, then.”

“Of course,” he said, and now with the hand free of the crown, he offered it to Arya, to walk her down from the stands. As people prepared the camp and King Robert set the rules: “three shots, the one who gets closer to the center wins.”

They chosed their bows and arrows and they were ready, Arya offering Gendry the first shots.

“Ladies should go first,” he announced.

“You’re the Prince, the right is yours,” she argued and the King told Gendry to go; and then Arya added in a quieter voice only for his benefit, “And I’m no lady, Gendry.”

He laughed and made the three shots: two on the center and then one on the second ring. People clapped for their prince, sure that he would win, Gendry wasn’t as sure, that arrow on the second ring could be his undoing.

It was. Arya took her time with the bow, but each arrow it dead center, spitting the previous arrows in a half with the second and third turn.

“My prince,” she said with the bow, lifting her now muddy dress like she had been thought.

“My lady, you’re a worthy adversary.”

“You too, my Prince.”

“The crown, please?” she asked and he put it on her hands once again.

“It still counts as winning the bet, correct?” he whispered and she shrugged her shoulders with a smile, before adding to the public, “Here’s the crown. Who will recieve this honor?”his

“Thank you,” she said. “I name the most beautiful lady in this tourney, Queen of Love and Beauty,” she said walking to where Gendry had walked to previously. “Mother, if you would accept the honor?” Arya asked.

Catelyn, who had been exasperated by her daughter’s behavior, couldn’t help but smile at her daughter’s gesture; Ned helped her stand and walk her down the stalls.

“Can I?” her father asked when they reached Arya and she couldn’t reach her mother’s head, Ned took the crown of flowers, that brought him memories he didn’t want to remember, and placed them on his wife’s head as his daughter announced.

“I crown Lady Catelyn Stark Queen of Love and Beauty for all to see.” Claps were heard through the tourney, none louder than Sansa’s, that was able to forgive her sister’s careless and immature actions for the honor she gave their mother.

“Thank you, sweetling,” Catelyn thanked Arya as she came to take her seat once again, squeezing her fingers. “But you shouldn’t question the prince.”

“Gendry doesn’t mind and you deserve the crown more than I.”

“No, I don’t. You’re more beautiful than I could ever be,” Catelyn said with a smile and kiss on Arya’s forehead, “both my daughters are,” she added, squeezing Sansa’s hand as well. And Arya smiled at her mother’s words, not convinced that she was more beautiful than her mother, no one was, but believing that maybe she could be beautiful too, she could accept it as long as she could fight as well.

Thank you so much for the prompt :) I don’t think I ever wrote Gendry as the crown prince, that changes a lot about him and who he is… I tried to find the balance in that

The stupid stag was not going to do it. He was not. He was not. Arya kept repeating to herself. It had been a stupid bet Hot Pie from the Inn had proposed Gendry, with a easiness you normally didn’t see between a baker and a crown prince. Arya had obviously opposed the bet, multiple times, and she told him she wouldn’t accept it, so no, she couldn’t believe he was coming her way.

“My son,” Robert yelled with a laugh, “have you chosen a Queen of Love and Beauty?”

“Yes, Your Grace,” he answered and walked up to her, “My lady,” he greeted her, “I offer this crown to Lady Arya Stark.”

“No,” she answered with a smile to his own, as Mother and Sansa tried to stop her. “No,” she repeated.

[[MORE]]

“We’re quite in a impasse now, my lady. What do you purpose?” Gendry asked smiling - he knew why she was saying no, to challenge him.

“A competition. You win, I accept the crown; I win, I get the crown and name who I want.”

“Yes, yes, bring on another competition,” the King yelled from the place where he was seeing everything. “Choose, girl. Choose. A fighting spirit like my Lyanna.” Silence followed after that, as it was expected when King Robert brought up Lyanna - he had never married, saying that there would be no one to compare. But without heirs, he had chosen a few of his bastards to legitimize - Gendry had been one of the oldest and one of the closest to him, right here in King’s Landing.

“Prince Gendry, if you need the pick,” Arya finally spoke when King Robert had looked up from his grief.

“I’ll take your choice.”

“Archery, then.”

“Of course,” he said, and now with the hand free of the crown, he offered it to Arya, to walk her down from the stands. As people prepared the camp and King Robert set the rules: “three shots, the one who gets closer to the center wins.”

They chosed their bows and arrows and they were ready, Arya offering Gendry the first shots.

“Ladies should go first,” he announced.

“You’re the Prince, the right is yours,” she argued and the King told Gendry to go; and then Arya added in a quieter voice only for his benefit, “And I’m no lady, Gendry.”

He laughed and made the three shots: two on the center and then one on the second ring. People clapped for their prince, sure that he would win, Gendry wasn’t as sure, that arrow on the second ring could be his undoing.

It was. Arya took her time with the bow, but each arrow it dead center, spitting the previous arrows in a half with the second and third turn.

“My prince,” she said with the bow, lifting her now muddy dress like she had been thought.

“My lady, you’re a worthy adversary.”

“You too, my Prince.”

“The crown, please?” she asked and he put it on her hands once again.

“It still counts as winning the bet, correct?” he whispered and she shrugged her shoulders with a smile, before adding to the public, “Here’s the crown. Who will recieve this honor?”his

“Thank you,” she said. “I name the most beautiful lady in this tourney, Queen of Love and Beauty,” she said walking to where Gendry had walked to previously. “Mother, if you would accept the honor?” Arya asked.

Catelyn, who had been exasperated by her daughter’s behavior, couldn’t help but smile at her daughter’s gesture; Ned helped her stand and walk her down the stalls.

“Can I?” her father asked when they reached Arya and she couldn’t reach her mother’s head, Ned took the crown of flowers, that brought him memories he didn’t want to remember, and placed them on his wife’s head as his daughter announced.

“I crown Lady Catelyn Stark Queen of Love and Beauty for all to see.” Claps were heard through the tourney, none louder than Sansa’s, that was able to forgive her sister’s careless and immature actions for the honor she gave their mother.

“Thank you, sweetling,” Catelyn thanked Arya as she came to take her seat once again, squeezing her fingers. “But you shouldn’t question the prince.”

“Gendry doesn’t mind and you deserve the crown more than I.”

“No, I don’t. You’re more beautiful than I could ever be,” Catelyn said with a smile and kiss on Arya’s forehead, “both my daughters are,” she added, squeezing Sansa’s hand as well. And Arya smiled at her mother’s words, not convinced that she was more beautiful than her mother, no one was, but believing that maybe she could be beautiful too, she could accept it as long as she could fight as well.

tags: a song of ice and fire
title: The Wood Dancer
body:
Arya is as wild and fierce as ever, but she’s much happier in this AU.

It’s a common joke around the castle that Arya was such a wild baby that she frightened off the House’s first septa, Mordane. Arya maintains that her bad behavior was an excuse, nothing more, pointing out that the only septa they’ve ever managed to keep is a spy for the Faith. Opinions are torn on who’s actually right.

This Arya grew up knowing that a war was on its way, a war that wouldn’t care about sex or age or station. She also grew up near several female warriors: the free folk spearwives who sometimes come to the castle, her mother’s Mormont ladies-in-waiting, assorted crannogwomen, singers of the song of earth, the visiting women of the hill tribes, and her own ghostly kin. Like her brothers Robb and Bran, Arya can see the ghosts of Winterfell, and the Stark women of old told her to tell her parents that they’d train her in swordsmanship if she didn’t get a living tutor.

Ned and Cat very wisely chose to get her living tutors: the wood dancers of the singers of the song of earth. They knew from an early age that Arya would grow up small and slim and strong, so they reasoned that the singers’ fighting style would suit her more than, say, Mormont ax-fighting.

They were absolutely right. Arya took to the wood dancers’ knives, spears, and arrows like a fish to water–but she wanted to learn the sword as well, so Ned sent to Braavos for a water dancer, correctly believing that the Braavosi style would suit her. Syrio Forel is a bit eccentric, but he gets along well with his pupil and has even been known to teach others (mostly singers and crannogfolk) his techniques. Arya has managed to create a blended style all her own, and she is very, very good at it.

This Arya gets along much better with Sansa and Catelyn. She doesn’t feel any need to live up to her sister’s accomplishments in the ladylike arts, and her mother doesn’t try to force her into it. The lack of a consistent, non-spy septa helps with this, too. Additionally, Arya has ways of bonding with her female relatives that didn’t exist in canon. She helps Sansa with her research by talking with the ghosts of Winterfell, whom Sansa can’t see. (This has made Arya very fluent in the Old Tongue, and Syrio’s taught her quite a bit of Braavosi.) She’s also fascinated with her mother’s spy network and is learning quite a bit about espionage at her mother’s knee. She even gets lessons from Bloodraven sometimes. It would surprise absolutely no one if Arya were to succeed Cat as Winterfell’s unofficial Mistress of Whispers.

Jon Snow is still her favorite sibling and best friend, though. She taught him the harp, he wrote her a song. He helped teach her swordplay–namely how to fight against traditionally trained Westerosi–and she promised that next time she finds a magic sword, she’ll give it to him. (Considering that she’s already found one magic sword in the godswood pool, this is more likely than you’d think.) Since Stark children are told about Jon’s heritage at age twelve, she doesn’t know yet that he’s technically her cousin–or at least she’s not supposed to. She actually figured it out a couple years ago but decided that Jon will tell her when he’s ready, and it’s not like this makes him any less her brother.

(That being said, it’s a very good thing so few people can see ghosts. If they could, they’d probably pay attention when Rhaegar Targaryen comes to visit… and they might notice that he and Jon Snow have the same laugh.)

Arya is a skilled warg, able to slip into both her direwolf Nymeria and one of the castle cats. She’s also displayed an affinity for the singers’ brand of illusion magic, though due to her young age and the lack of dragons and the magic they bring into the world she hasn’t been trained much in this. After hearing Syrio’s tales of the Faceless Men, she tried to get her parents to bring one to the Academy, but they put their foot down. 

(On a completely unrelated note, Syrio Forel may or may not have sent off a letter to an old friend of his who may or may not be on the way to Winterfell.)

When winter comes, Arya probably won’t be on the front lines of battle. Her style of fighting isn’t particularly suited for that. But she will be somewhere in the fray, fighting to keep her pack safe.
body_abstract: Arya is as wild and fierce as ever, but she’s much happier in this AU.

title: Sansa at Littlefinger’s Trial
body:
You know how some people have been saying that Sansa is not a Stark and most definitely not true to her father’s teachings, because she was the one to sentence Littlefinger to death, yet she did not “swing the sword”.

It’s been bugging me since  f o r e v e r.

a. The whole point of this scene was to show how Littlefinger did not succeed in breaking the pack apart. What we see is Sansa serving as the judge, Arya as the executioner, and Bran providing all the “evidence”. The lone wolf dies, the pack survives. It’s not just Sansa who makes it happen, it’s all three of them. I mean Sansa is obviously the leader, serving both as the Lady of Winterfell and the de facto acting Queen in the North (in Jon’s absence), but we aren’t witnessing her personal vendetta but rather a presentation of an extended list of Littlefinger’s crimes against the Starks, the North and the Vale.

b. I think we are relying too much on the exact wording of the sentence: “The man who passes the sentence should swing the sword” and ignoring the rest of Ned’s lesson. It is mentioned both in Jon’s and Arya’s POVs in “The Clash of Kings”:


But she didn’t think she should trust Jaqen. I should kill them myself. Whenever her father had condemned a man to death, he did the deed himself with Ice, his greatsword. “If you would take a man’s life, you owe it to him to look him in the face and hear his last words,” she’d heard him tell Robb and Jon once.

Arya VII, “The Clash of Kings”


“My father never used a headsman. He said he owed it to men he killed to look into their eyes and hear their last words.”

Jon VII, “The Clash of Kings”


Isn’t that what Sansa did? She listened to Littlefinger’s last words, she confronted him, she heard him beg for his life, but she still decided that he deserved to die for his crimes (unlike Jon who saw no evil in Ygritte and thus spared her). She did absolutely everything by the book (apart from literally swinging the blade, since she had never done it in her entire life, and even if she attempted to do it then, Littlefinger’s death would be much more painful and so much messier). Does it mean that in order to be the Queen and/or the Lady of Winterfell she must learn how to physically take lives? No. It means that the most important thing about condemning a man to death is being able to value the life you are taking and being aware of the grim finality of your decision. Which. She. Was.

Sansa did nothing wrong and nothing against her “Starkness”, lay off her.

#Sansa Stark Defence Squad

summary:
Septa Mordane: You have fifteen seconds to figure out what’s wrong with Arya.
Catelyn: THERE’S NOTHING WRONG WITH HER!
Septa:...
body:
Septa Mordane: You have fifteen seconds to figure out what’s wrong with Arya.

Catelyn: THERE’S NOTHING WRONG WITH HER!

Septa: *looks over at Arya staring at a bunch of knives*

Septa: Yes. Yes, there is.
